<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 881, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate temperature changes when mixing hot and cold water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 128, 848, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 392, 532, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 144, 442]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 424, 615, 442]]<|/det|>
Use the thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 454, 920, 473]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .................................. \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 144, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 485, 536, 504]]<|/det|>
· Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 516, 165, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 516, 915, 535]]<|/det|>
Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}}\) of the cold water. \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}} =\) ......................................... \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 547, 185, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 547, 636, 566]]<|/det|>
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water provided into beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 579, 168, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 579, 915, 598]]<|/det|>
Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water. \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\) ......................................... \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 610, 175, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 610, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
Immediately pour the cold water into the hot water in beaker B. Stir the mixture and record the highest temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the mixture.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 655, 920, 674]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\) ......................................... \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 672, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 782, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the position of the image in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions. Use the ray-trace sheet supplied, referring to Fig. 2.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 147, 776, 612]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 628, 532, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 120]]<|/det|> Draw a line 10 cm long near the middle of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 166]]<|/det|> Draw a line 7.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(\alpha = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 144, 198]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 180, 707, 198]]<|/det|> Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 175, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 920, 247]]<|/det|> Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 260, 175, 279]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 260, 920, 316]]<|/det|> View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 2.1. Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 316, 920, 333]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 146, 364]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 345, 920, 378]]<|/det|> Remove the pins and the mirror. Draw a line through the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{MR}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 392, 866, 410]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the acute angle \(\beta\) between this line and the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 422, 541, 440]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[309, 448, 690, 527]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha /\mathrm {o}\)\(\beta /\mathrm {o}\)\((\alpha +\beta )/\mathrm {o}\)
30
45
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 547]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 559, 144, 577]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 559, 787, 577]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure in (b), (c) and (d) using an angle of incidence \(\alpha = 45^{\circ}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 440, 607]]<|/det|> Record the value of \(\beta\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 590, 920, 609]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 621, 144, 640]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 621, 616, 640]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the values of \((\alpha +\beta)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 621, 920, 640]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 652, 146, 670]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 652, 787, 670]]<|/det|> Suggest a relationship, if any, between the two values of \((\alpha +\beta)\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 682, 920, 700]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(h)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
In order to investigate further a possible relationship between values of \((\alpha + \beta)\), more values are required.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
Suggest values of the angle of incidence \(\alpha\) that you could use. You are **not** required to do this further investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 195, 918, 212]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 141, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 497, 245]]<|/det|>
A student does this experiment with care.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Suggest a practical reason why the results may not be exactly those that the theory of reflection predicts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[881, 335, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 729, 384]]<|/det|>
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this booklet between pages 6 and 7.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 677, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the balancing of a metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 128, 893, 266]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 280, 532, 299]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 146, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 311, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
Place the metre rule on the pivot, with its scale facing upwards, so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. Record the scale reading \(S\) on the metre rule at the point where the rule balances on the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 387, 920, 406]]<|/det|>
<form>S = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 388, 920, 406]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 146, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 420, 752, 439]]<|/det|>
• Place object Q with its centre on the metre rule at the 90.0 cm mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 451, 626, 470]]<|/det|>
• Place a load P of weight \(P = 1.0 \text{N}\) on the metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|> Adjust the position of the load P so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. The pivot must remain directly below the scale reading S. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(a\) from the centre of load P to the centre of load Q, as shown in Fig. 3.2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 158, 888, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 322, 534, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 352, 181, 371]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 352, 848, 371]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps above, using loads of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}\), \(3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\) and \(5.0 \text{N}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 383, 512, 401]]<|/det|> Record all the values of \(a\) in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 415, 541, 432]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 440, 678, 612]]<|/det|>
\(P/\mathrm {N}\)\(a/\mathrm {cm}\)\(\frac {1}{P}/\frac {1}{N}\)
1.01.00
2.00.50
3.00.33
4.00.25
5.00.20
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|> [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(a / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{1}{P} /\frac{1}{N}\) (x-axis). Start the \(y\)-axis at \(a / \text{cm} = 30\). Start the \(x\)-axis at 0.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 135, 791, 553]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 583, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 612, 146, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 606, 920, 648]]<|/det|>
Record the value of a when \(\frac{1}{P} = 0\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 658, 920, 679]]<|/det|>
<form>a = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 689, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 160]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect on the resistance of a wire when the tension in the wire is increased. The apparatus is shown in Fig. 4.1. The tension in the wire is increased by adding loads to the hook attached to the wire. The student measures the current \(I\) in the wire and the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the wire. She determines the resistance \(R\) of the wire using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 178, 536, 196]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 209, 918, 243]]<|/det|>
The student takes all the necessary safety precautions. You are **not** required to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 256, 420, 274]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 288, 322, 304]]<|/det|>
· resistance wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 615, 336]]<|/det|>
· power source, connecting wires and crocodile clips

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 351, 275, 366]]<|/det|>
· ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 381, 275, 396]]<|/det|>
· voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 412, 460, 428]]<|/det|>
· selection of loads and a hanger.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 437, 841, 675]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 688, 532, 705]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect on the resistance of a wire when the tension in the wire is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 218, 135]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 133, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the resistance wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 133, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 618, 215]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 133, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>
